Headline.Para: Ezion's road to redemption starts with shareholders' meeting today

LeadPara.Para: The group can pare its debts to a manageable level only with the support of all stakeholders

TailParas.Para: OFFSHORE and marine (O&M) group, Ezion Holdings, is looking to win shareholders' approval at an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) on Wednesday, for a debt refinancing plan that will allow the group a fighting chance to ride through the rest of a prolonged sectoral downturn.

The plan involves shareholders voting to dilute their interest, by enabling the company to issue new shares to creditors and other stakeholders. Once the debt refinancing is approved, shareholders will receive warrants.
It also hinges on secured and unsecured creditors exercising the options to exchange debts, which have priority over equity, for new ordinary shares.
Both sets of stakeholders must agree to this course of action in order for Ezion to emerge with a more manageable debt burden.
And that is a tough task, as group chief financial officer, Paul Goon, has acknowledged in an exclusive interview with The Business Times,

Mr Goon pointed out that Ezion's net gearing ratio, which surged to a whopping 4.5 times after taking in a massive impairment of US$900 million for FY2017, will fall to just 1.5 times, inclusive of accrued interests and joint venture loans, after its debt refinancing is completed.
This is based on certain key assumptions underpinning this deleveraging of Ezion's balance sheet.

Firstly, the projected net gearing ratio post-refinancing assumes that holders of the group's issued notes and its secured lenders would have exercised the options granted to them to convert US$340 million of notes - representing just under 80 per cent of the outstanding notes - as well as up to US$33 million of senior loans into shares.
Secondly, Ezion hopes to raise up to US$486 million OF new equity from the exercise of warrants issued to shareholders, security holders and other stakeholders.
This projection includes US$381 million that will be injected into the company once shareholders exercise all of their allotted warrants.

Mr Goon argued that it is in the interest of shareholders to do so as it will "reduce the dilution" of existing equity stakes if security holders and senior lenders exercise their share conversion options.
If these new injections come to fruition, Ezion will see its equity base expand to about US$1 billion, up from about US$300 million (after taking into account the US$900 million impairment charge).
Mr Goon added that once all elements of this debt-refinancing plan fall in place, Ezion stands to stay viable through at least the next six years.

The group will have the maturity of senior loans that ranged from one to four years before refinancing, extended to six years after the target completion of its debt refinancing this year. Only minimal capital repayments will be required for these senior loans throughout this extra runway. Post-refinancing, the principal values of the holding company's senior loans will stand at US$967 million, down from US$1 billion. On a consolidated basis, the group will have about US$1.5 billion of total debts, including accrued interests and joint venture loans.
According to Mr Goon, Ezion will not need to undertake any further debt refinancing if its plan succeeds.

On the US$900 million impairment unveiled last week, BT understands that this relates mainly to a combined fleet of about 60 units of service rigs, offshore support vessels and barges on Ezion's fleet. Also included in this impairment charge are provisions extended to trade receivables.
Mr Goon said that the plan going forward is to divest about half of the combined fleet of service rigs, OSVs and barges.

Ezion has guided during the consent solicitation exercise with its security holders that it expects to generate US$900 million in net operating cash flow over the next six years. Two thirds of this projected cash flow will come from liftboats and the rest from the other assets.
It is assumed with this cash flow projection, that it will put all 14liftboats out to work by the end of 2018 and its other assets will achieve an overall utilisation of about 50 per cent.
Ezion warned last week that it will post a net loss of US$1 billion for fourth quarter and full year, mainly due to some US$900 million in impairment losses.
It will unveil details of these losses on Wednesday.
